claim: All contracts must be written to be valid

supporting.text: Oral contracts are legally enforceable in many jurisdictions if they meet the basic requirements of offer, acceptance, and consideration.

attacks.text: Oral contracts are legally enforceable in many jurisdictions if they meet the basic requirements of offer, acceptance, and consideration.
Oral contracts are harder to prove in court due to the lack of written evidence, making them less reliable than written contracts.
Many jurisdictions require certain types of contracts, such as real estate transactions, to be in writing to be enforceable.
Oral contracts can be subject to misunderstandings or disputes over the exact terms agreed upon.
Witness testimony and other forms of evidence can be used to substantiate the terms of an oral contract.

supporting.text: Implied contracts, formed through the conduct of parties, are valid without any written documentation.

attacks.text: Implied contracts, formed through the conduct of parties, are valid without any written documentation.
Implied contracts are harder to enforce in court due to lack of clear documentation.
Many jurisdictions recognize and enforce implied contracts based on consistent legal precedents.
Certain types of contracts, such as real estate transactions, are required by law to be in writing.
While some contracts must be written, this does not negate the validity of implied contracts in other contexts.

supporting.text: Certain types of contracts, such as those for small purchases or services, are routinely formed verbally and upheld in court.

attacks.text: Certain types of contracts, such as those for small purchases or services, are routinely formed verbally and upheld in court.
Verbal contracts are harder to enforce due to lack of documentation, leading to disputes over terms.
Many jurisdictions recognize verbal contracts only for transactions below a certain monetary threshold, limiting their applicability.
Statute of Frauds in many legal systems requires certain contracts to be written to be enforceable, such as real estate transactions or agreements lasting over a year.
Even under the Statute of Frauds, partial performance or admission in court can sometimes validate an otherwise unenforceable verbal agreement.

supporting.text: The Statute of Frauds, while requiring some contracts to be written, explicitly acknowledges that many contracts do not need to be written to be valid.

attacks.text: The Statute of Frauds, while requiring some contracts to be written, explicitly acknowledges that many contracts do not need to be written to be valid.
The Statute of Frauds is limited to specific types of contracts (e.g., real estate, marriage, contracts not performable within one year), so it does not cover all contracts universally.
Even outside the Statute of Frauds, courts often require written evidence for complex or high-value contracts to prevent disputes, implying a practical necessity for writing.
Oral contracts are legally binding in many jurisdictions if they meet basic requirements like offer, acceptance, and consideration, regardless of writing.
Enforcing oral contracts is often difficult due to lack of evidence, making them practically unreliable despite legal validity.

supporting.text: Historical legal systems, such as common law, recognized and enforced verbal agreements long before written contracts became standard.

attacks.text: Historical legal systems, such as common law, recognized and enforced verbal agreements long before written contracts became standard.
Modern legal systems often require written contracts for enforceability, especially for complex or high-value agreements.
Even in modern systems, certain verbal agreements (e.g., simple service contracts) can still be legally binding under specific conditions.
Statutes of fraud in many jurisdictions mandate written contracts for specific types of agreements, such as real estate transactions.

supporting.text: International trade often relies on verbal agreements or conduct, which are legally binding under the United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods (CISG).

attacks.text: International trade often relies on verbal agreements or conduct, which are legally binding under the United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods (CISG).
The CISG applies only to contracts for the international sale of goods, not to all types of contracts, such as real estate or employment contracts.
Even under the CISG, parties can opt out of its provisions and require written contracts, which is common in practice to avoid disputes.
Many jurisdictions outside the CISG framework require written contracts for certain types of agreements to be enforceable, such as those involving real estate or lasting more than one year.
The Statute of Frauds in common law countries mandates written contracts for specific types of agreements, reinforcing the claim that not all contracts can be verbal.
